title.text: A Comparison of Hedged and Non-hedged NLG Texts

abstractContent.text: We assess the use of hedge phrases in "affec-tive" NLG texts.
A simple experiment suggests non-native speakers prefer texts that contain hedge phrases, but native speakers prefer texts that do not contain hedge phrases.

introductionContent.text: In recent years there has been growing interest in "affective" Natural Language Generation (NLG).
Affective NLG has been defined as: "NLG that relates to, arises from or deliberately influences emotions or other non-strictly rational aspects of the Hearer" (.
One open issue in affective NLG is how texts that communicate emotionally sensitive information should be worded.
In this paper we focus on the usage of 'hedge phrases' which communicate empathetic information, such as "unfortunately."

An experiment in the domain of communicating exam results to students suggests that such emphathetic hedge phrases are appreciated by non-native English speakers, but disliked by native English speakers.

datasetContent.text: The questionnaire asked each participant fora set of personal details; Age, English fluency level, and gender.

The main questionnaire then consisted of two sections as described in the previous section.: A section of the questionnaire given to participants Subjects were asked to state a preference which ran from -3 for Text A to + 3 for Text B. If both texts were considered by a participant to be the same then a score of 0 was given.
The participants were asked to provide free text comments on why they made their particular choice of text.
